subject: Have you met the new Microsoft Teams?
body:
You don't often get email from teams@communication.microsoft.com. 
Learn why this is important
Users of new Teams are finding more focus and fun across work, school, and life. We’re listening to the 320 million people who rely on Teams every month and sharing some of the experiences they love most for you to go try. 
 
 
Have you met the new Microsoft Teams?
 
Users of new Teams are finding more focus and fun across work, school, and life. We’re listening to the 320 million people who rely on Teams every month and sharing some of the experiences they love most for you to go try. 
New to new Teams?
As the world continues to evolve, Teams is here to be your modern workplace. Check out the video to learn more about the new and unique experiences we’re building for new Teams.
 
Fan favorites
 
 
Celebrate success using Together Emojis
Foster shared sentiments and a sense of belonging. Simply type (highfive) to initiate a virtual high-five, and your colleagues can join in the fun by typing (highfive) for a group cheer. 
Learn more
Express who you are through Teams backgrounds 
Change what appears behind you in your video meeting or call. You can blur your background, replace it entirely with any image you want, or use a Teams virtual background template. 
Learn more
Let AI filter out the background noise from wherever you work
Working in a busy coffee shop? Taking your call from the airport? Turn on voice isolation to eliminate unwanted background noise and other voices that can interfere with your Teams calls and meetings.
Learn more
These are just a few of the great features that our users love. Visit the 
Teams website
 to discover even more. Your next productivity breakthrough awaits!

subject: RE: Ubisoft Updates
body:
Thanks to you both.
 
Tamara
 
From:
 Bastian Küntzel <bastian@incontro-training.org> 
Sent:
 Friday, July 21, 2023 2:24 AM
To:
 Annelie Wambeek <A.wambeek@lcwmail.com>; Tamara Thorpe <t.thorpe@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Conner Williams <c.williams@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Re: Ubisoft Updates
 
Hi Tamara, 
Thank you so much for this extensive update. Good to hear that things are moving and evolving in Ubisoft. 
Frankly, I do agree with the feedback and the criticism about the Leader programme that Raashi has voiced. The programme was, in a way, developed with a lot of people involved, with many compromises, trying to achieve probably too many things. And yes, it was very unfortunate that neither Annelie nor myself had had a chance to see the e-learning before it was sent to participants. It’s a difficult position to be in, as you can appreciate, to on the one hand run a programme that was not developed by us (meaning Annelie and myself), respond to participants in a dynamic way, and inevitably frustrate the need for easy solutions where there are none. But that all comes with the job :-) 
I’m looking forward to hearing what’s on the horizon when things become more concrete. As you know, in 2023 I’m still available with limited capacity, so it’s always good to know as early as possible if you would like my participation in something. 
Have a lovely weekend everyone! 
 
Warm Greetings, Beste Grüße, Pozdrawiam!
Bastian Küntzel 
 
www.incontro-training.org
+48-696 3666 43 
My recent creative outputs: 
TEDx Talk
 | 
book
 | 
podcast
 | 
online course
On 21 Jul 2023 at 02:38 +0200, Tamara Thorpe <
t.thorpe@lcwmail.com
>, wrote:
Hello Annelie and Bastian,
 
Hope you both are well and enjoying summer!
 
As you know, Raphelle has been on maternity leave; she gave birth to a healthy baby girl she named Rebecca. She will be back in the office sometime in August. In the interim, we’ve been working closely with her temporary replacement, Ana, who had not been previously involved in our partnership. She has offered some very helpful insights and feedback that we have been implementing as the programme evolves.
 
One of the more important conversations that we have had have been about scheduling and participation. As you know, we have struggled with scheduling and late cancellations, and low participation in our virtual sessions. As a result, Raashi has gotten involved and has committed to taking greater efforts on their end to ensure less rescheduling and greater participation.
 
One of the steps Raashi has taken is to have one to one conversations with participants from both the Leaders and HR Upskilling cohorts. In those conversations, Raashi gathered some additional feedback about the facilitated sessions, both content and delivery.
 
With regards to the HR Upskilling programming, folks are quite pleased with the content and new efforts are going to ensure greater participation. 
The next cohort is coming up, we will likely kick off in September, Conner will be reaching out to you about facilitation dates soon.
 
For the Leaders Academy, there was mixed feedback from Raashi and participants. Overall, there is a sense that the experience has declined from cohort to cohort. Feedback was that the content is too theoretical and not focused enough on action. Obviously, this is a content issue which we discussed with Raashi, while also making her aware of the various contributing factors. One of the largest contributing factors is not having enough time in person, and how we have broken up the content. We agreed that for all future cohorts we will have a new format:
Part 1 Virtual
Part 2 In person
Part 3 Virtual
 
With regards to facilitation, participants expressed that they did not think there were getting tangible takeaways, that they often heard “it depends”, and that they were wanting more guidance from the facilitators. Which, of course, I know is tricky.
 
Additionally, Raashi and some folks she talked appreciated your dynamic style, but were frustrated with the fact that neither of you were familiar with the eLearning content, and were unprepared to answer their questions as it related to the eLearning. I realize that this was a change in the curriculum with little notice, and we won’t be using it with this population again.
 
Ultimately, Raashi’s feeling is that the facilitation isn’t working and she would like us to take a different approach. This may include delivering the training with an internal Ubisoft facilitator who can speak to the specific issues within Ubisoft with greater authority. However, this has not been confirmed. But if this is the case then we think it best that an internal LCW facilitator collaborate with their internal facilitator.
 
There are two additional Leaders cohorts coming up in October and November,  I won’t likely be able to confirm the facilitation needs until Raphaelle returns in August.
 
We are extending our contract with them to continue to develop programming in 2024 so I’ll keep you posted as things progress.
 
Thank you both so much for your being such incredible partners, sharing your expertise and lived experiences, and for being so incredibly patient and flexible with us and Ubisoft.
 
We look forward to our continued collaboration.
 
Tamara and Conner
 
 
Tamara Thorpe
(she/her)
Principal Consultant
LCW

subject: Ubisoft Updates
body:
Hello Bastian and Annelie,
 
Hope you are both well; we met with Raphaelle this morning, our last before she goes on Maternity leave. She will be reaching out to both of you to get your feedback on Cohort 6, particularly any insights on low attendance for Part 3.
 
I am absolutely aware and 100% in support of having all of our content delivered in person, and it is my hope that as they evaluate Cohorts 1-6m they reconsider the format. Raphaelle meets with Caroline, who is in charge of the format for the Leadership Academy, on Tuesday to discuss feedback and future formats. I’m confident that RL is aware that we would like our entire session delivered in person. We will have to wait to hear from her after she’s met with Caroline on formats for the future.
 
Additionally, we discussed adjusting the content for Content for Cohort 5, Parts 2 and 3. We want to give them more time for discussion and practice. RL is going to review the content and make recommendations for what she things we can exclude; and Part 2 may look more like what you did for the last on site with Cohort 6. I’ll keep you updated and if you have recommendations, please send them to me.
 
Thanks again,
Tamara
 
 
 
-
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Tamara Thorpe (she/her)
Principal Consultant, LCW
Email: t.thorpe@lcwmail.com
Phone: +1-773-888-4942

subject: RE: Ubi Follow-Ups
body:
Yes, this was the part of the text that she took offence with. Which I get. If possible, it might make sense to rewrite that to make it a little less sweeping? 
Bastian Küntzel

nd

If we can meet after my meeting with RL this week, that would be great.
 
Tamara

subject: RE: Content adjustment for Cohort 6
body:
Thanks Bastian! I’ll go through these tomorrow and update you on the integration.
 
Much appreciated.
 
Tamara
 
From:
 Bastian Küntzel <bastian@incontro-training.org> 
Sent:
 Sunday, February 19, 2023 10:54 AM
To:
 Annelie Wambeek <hello@anneliewambeek.com>; Annelie Wambeek <A.wambeek@lcwmail.com>; Tamara Thorpe <t.thorpe@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Conner Williams <c.williams@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Re: Content adjustment for Cohort 6
 
Hi Tamara, 
Annelie and I just got together and we have some ideas for a little re-design of the in-person session: 
After a quick intro: 
The video of the woman and the man (I know this simulation under the name of Albatros) and going right into the DIIN Model. 
Then linking to the I, exploring where the interpretation perspectives come from and going straight into the Diversity Wheel. But before we do it, we do the Twenty Statement Test (asking participants to answer the question ‘Who are you’ twenty times. Then using the Diversity Wheel to look at what categories they mainly used to describe themselves, which they didn’t use. Which put them in powerful majority positions, which in minority positions, which in powerful positions, which may cause them to be stereotyped or discriminated against, etc. 
We then link that to the idea of ‘I see you’ and ask the question - When we, as inclusive leaders, want to understand deeper how we interpret what we experience and understand deeper how others interpret what they experience what do we need to get better at? 
We then provide the D&I Strategic Pillars (Community, Content, Colleagues, Culture) and ask them, maybe in small groups?, to list their Ambitions (What?), Fears, Motivations (Why?), and their existing tools (Skills and knowledge) - possibly specific even for each pillar? 
We then contextualise the second and third module as being all about the N aspect of the DIIN Model, equipping them to navigate each relationship. 
 
Warm Greetings, Beste Grüße, Pozdrawiam!
Bastian Küntzel
